title: Make sure nanny thread is protected against exceptions.
body:
Protect each of the 3 subcalls of the nanny thread against exceptions.  PG2-262
1. killStragglers is not related to the data structures and is just a startup/teardown action
2. addWarmContainer can fail to create the container in which case it is not introduced into the data structure
3. teardownContainer only operates on containers in a toBeRemoved list which means they are not logically in the data structure anymore

title: [proposal ]consume timestamp parameter from kafka records and log in activation …
body:
…feed

The broker adds a timestamp when a message get's created in kafka. This PR will read the timestamp from the record consumed and print in activation feed along with the pipeline occupancy. It's supposed to give some insights how long the messages live in the queue.

ideally, the timestamp should be printed with the tid. need to figure out how to do. suggestions?

alternative would be to extend the ActivationMessage and set the timestamp in the controller. would prefer the proposed option.

reference: https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/KAFKA/KIP-32+-+Add+timestamps+to+Kafka+message#KIP-32-AddtimestampstoKafkamessage-Brokerconfigurationchange

title: quick-start with docker-compose
body:
I'm looking to get your feedback and I'm sharing my early progress for a simpler setup for Mac using `docker-compose` with Docker `1.10` and above ( I'm currently testing with `1.12.1` )

I'm using a `Makefile` providing 2 commands: `make run` and `make stop`. 
My end-goal would be to create `make quick-start` which could potentially handle the build then invoke `make run`. 

I'm thinking that for people like me that want to get started ASAP and have struggles with ansible and the particular local setup with other dependencies like python, etc, `docker-compose` is a faster way to get started. 

For people using ansible for deployment in other environments, having a local sandbox for ansible is of great help. For this use-case I'm wondering if a VM can be a better choice as it doesn't surface OS X specifics problems, as it could be an Ubuntu/CentOS/others.     

In this way both options could be maintained and the community can choose the one that fits best for a particular setup.

> NOTE: This is WIP. I'll update the PR title once I get something working end to end.

title: Fixes two errors in invoke path
body:
1. if docker pull fails for black box container, do not attempt to run container
2. if action is a black box, set appropriate bits correctly

FYI @markusthoemmes @psuter.
Fixes #1149.

Note that at the level of the docker pull/run command we can't distinguish (without additional context) if the command fails because it's a black box action or not. This should matter so that we can attribute the error to the appropriate status (internal vs client).

Rather than wrap operations with `Try` types because it is pervasive, I left the `throws` in place and handled the exception at the outermost level after writing them to a more specific type along the way (where the context is available).

title: replace InMemoryCache with new impl that avoids read under write race
body:
This PR introduces a new caching structure, to replace the existing `InMemoryCache`. The goal is to address the read-under-write and write-under-read race conditions discussed in #1260. 

I'm open to suggestions for better names for the new data structure.
### Summary of Data Structure

The new cache operates by:
- on an **_uncontested**_ read or write, it reserves a slot in the cache (i.e. reservation upon initiation)
- each slot (cache `Entry`) has a `State` that is used to determine how to proceed with contested operations. States are ReadInProgress, WriteInProgress, Cached, InvalidateInProgress
- **_contested**_ operations obey the state transition diagram discussed in #1260
- reads under reads are coalesced
- reads under writes read-around the cache
- writes under reads write-around the cache
### Extra Notes
- leverages #1289 to remove the multi-key updates that were previously in place.
- `InMemoryCache` used split get-then-put. This new cache leverages the putIfAbsent behavior of the underlying LRUCache --- necessarily now, in order to avoid races between the get and the put (now that we are reserving-upon-initiation).
### Testing
- localhost testing SUCCESS
- PG1 515 (two false flag failures -- timeouts in blackbox operations)
- PG1 519 SUCCESS
- Travis green

closes #1260

labels.name: review
labels.description: Review for this PR has been requested and yet needs to be done.

labels.description: Pipeline has approved this change.

title: Use new Identity in API router, authentication and authorization
body:
Introduces the foundation for limited scope keys: an activation only key with no CRUD rights. Commits are incremental and self-contained, working up to the point of using the new Identity type to reject requests to CRUD resources with activation keys.

This builds on #1254 (first two commits will be dropped from this pull request).

title: Add the deprecation script
body:
This patch adds a script to deprecate the packages and actions,
which have changed their names after the transition to openwhisk-catalog.

The package util has renamed to utils, and echo action has moved from
samples/echo to utils/echo.

title: Reify types in ActivationMessage
body:
Step 1 of several to come to allow activations to be stored in a specific namespace.
1. remove internal path in activation message
2. remove dispatcher matching of internal path to handlers (since there is only 1 now per dispatcher)
3. make fully qualified entity name a triple that includes an optional version
4. thread activation namespace from controller to the invoker (where the activation namespace is semantically preserving)

title: adding support for openstack persistent volumes
body: These proposed changes enhance the distributed ansible playbooks with the ability to create and attach a persistent disk to the couchdb instance. The size of the couchdb disk (in GB) can be set either as an environment variable (OS_WSK_DB_VOLUME=15) or in the instances object from environments/distributed/group_vars/all.
